an9.71:1.1: “Mendicants, there are five kinds of emotional barrenness.
an9.71:1.3: Firstly, a mendicant has doubts about the Teacher. They’re uncertain, undecided, and lacking confidence.
an9.71:1.4: This being so, their mind doesn’t incline toward keenness, commitment, persistence, and striving.
an9.71:1.5: This is the first kind of emotional barrenness.
an9.71:2.1: Furthermore, a mendicant has doubts about the teaching …
an9.71:2.4: A mendicant is angry and upset with their spiritual companions, resentful and closed off.
an9.71:2.5: This being so, their mind doesn’t incline toward keenness, commitment, persistence, and striving.
an9.71:2.6: This is the fifth kind of emotional barrenness.
an9.71:3.1: To give up these five kinds of emotional barrenness you should develop the four kinds of mindfulness meditation. …”
